Award.AwardTitle: Particle Astrophysics with IceCube at Georgia Tech
Award.AbstractNarration:
Embedded deep in the ice cap at the South Pole, the IceCube Neutrino Observatory (ICNO) is the world's largest and most sensitive high energy neutrino telescope. It is a 1 gigaton Cherenkov detector using the Antarctic ice as a detection medium for high energy atmospheric and astrophysical neutrinos. Most of the neutrinos observed by IceCube exhibit energies in the range expected for atmospheric neutrinos originating from decays of particles produced in extensive air showers by Cosmic Rays coming from nearby sectors of the Milky Way Galaxy. These may be used to measure the fundamental properties of neutrinos. At higher energies, astrophysical neutrinos are key probes of the high-energy universe. Because of their unique properties, neutrinos escape even dense regions, are not deflected by galactic or extra-galactic magnetic fields and traverse the photon-filled universe unhindered. Thus, neutrinos provide direct information about the dynamics and interiors of the powerful cosmic objects that may be the origins of high energy cosmic rays: supernovae, black holes, pulsars, active galactic nuclei and other extreme extragalactic phenomena.

Students and postdocs working on this project will benefit by training in particle astrophysics, instrumentation and data analysis of very large data sets. An educational program including high-school students, teachers and undergraduate students will continue. In collaboration with CEISMC and GoSTEM at Georgia Tech the PI and members of his group present lectures and hands on demonstrations on the topics of particle and nuclear physics and astrophysics.

The most powerful events in nature are usually transitory or episodic. Examples are the explosions of massive stars (core collapse supernovae, CC-SNe), high-energy emission by super-massive black holes at the center of galaxies (active galactic nuclei, AGNs), and the very energetic jets that power gamma-ray bursts (GRBs). This award will support the use of IceCube data to study very-high-energy neutrino astrophysical transients, including GRBs, choked GRBs and, potentially, still unknown types of astrophysical objects. The project will address two topics: a) Are choked GRBs related to CC-SNe and do they produce neutrinos? b) Are the sources of the astrophysical neutrino flux, recently discovered by IceCube, transient? Using IceCube data the Georgia Tech group will search for neutrino transients of one second to one day in duration in the 30 to 300 billion electron-volts energy range. The discovery of a neutrino burst with this search may reveal that CC-SNe and GRBs are part of a continuous class of astrophysical objects and that jets are also a feature of CC-SNe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Astrophysics has, for a long time, been carried out with light. This light may be visible to humans, or not. IceCube, a detector operating at the South Pole, has added a new messenger to astrophysics: not light, but neutrinos. Neutrino astrophysics is a major component of a nascent field: multi-messenger astrophysics. By combining all pieces of information from a given astrophysical object, the physical processes in operation at this object can be better understood.
The main objective of this grant was the study of sources of neutrinos that vary in time, they flare, or they are periodic and to correlate with multi-messenger data.

Intellectual Merit.

In 2013, IceCube discovered that neutrinos of astrophysical origin are arriving at Earth from all directions. The direction of each neutrino can only be determined with a precision of about 1/2 of a degree (diameter of the moon). There are an enormous number of astrophysical objects in a circle of 1/2 degree radius. Because of this, the class of objects that produce neutrinos is difficult to determine. But a multi-messenger approach may allow the identification of neutrino sources.

The first clue to the origin of the astrophysical neutrinos, came in 2017 and is one of the major outcomes of this grant. A likely astrophysical neutrino was observed in directional and temporal coincidence with a flare in gamma rays produced by a blazar. All large galaxies have a supermassive black hole at their center. Material, if present near the black hole, spirals down into the black hole, in an accretion disk. A blazar is one such black hole in which a small fraction of the material is ejected in a pair of jets and one of the jets points along our line of sight. This blazar is the first candidate astrophysical neutrino identified by IceCube. It's not clear if all the astrophysical neutrinos seen by IceCube are made by blazars. In this grant we have also searched for neutrinos from other sources including, periodic galactic sources and choked jets inside supernova explosions.

Broader Impacts:

Research for this grant was performed by the PI, one postdoc (fully funded for a period of 7 months) three PhD students (partially or fully funded by this grant) as well as by undergraduates (not funded via this grant). PhD and undergraduate students received training in data science, machine learning, dealing with very large data sets, etc. This training prepares students for both academic as well as industry jobs in the forefront of current technology. All group members participate in outreach and educational activities. Examples include yearly participation in the Atlanta Science Festival highlighting particle physics detectors. Visits to schools, astronomy clubs, etc. Interviews on radio, newspapers, etc.
